Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 50235-001  
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
August 2017 
 
 
 
Facilitating the Use of Country Safeguard Systems 
and Strengthening Safeguards Delivery 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Public Communications 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s

members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 28042017145707153671 Generated Date: 17-Aug-2017 11:47:56 AM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.   The strengthening and use of country systems is widely recognized as a means to improve 
aid effectiveness. Toward this end, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) pursues the use of 
country safeguard systems (CSS) as stipulated in the Safeguard Policy Statement (SPS) (2009). 
The proposed knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will strengthen CSS by facilitating 
their application, in lieu of ADB safeguard requirements, to identify and manage the environmental 
and social risks associated with ADB-supported projects. This will be achieved through the 
conduct of CSS assessments and capacity-building activities following the CSS assessment 
methodology.1 The TA will help realize the benefits of using CSS, which take the form of: (i) 
reducing transaction costs involved in project compliance with safeguards; (ii) strengthening the 
ownership of borrowers and clients of environmental and social safeguards; and (iii) harmonizing 
safeguard policies among donors.2 
 
2.  The TA is included in the Management-approved 2017 work program of the Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC), and is an endorsed corporate priority 
TA.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The SPS emphasizes a phased and demand-driven approach to the use of CSS. The 
demand has, however, been lower than the SPS Medium-Term Action Plan (2010–2012) had 
envisioned. According to the action plan, ADB was to support the use of CSS in 3–5 developing 
member countries (DMCs) (SPS, attachment 1, p. 89). To date, only two DMCs have requested 
ADB to consider such use: (i) the Government of Indonesia requested the use of its CSS for 
environment and involuntary resettlement safeguards in selected priority sectors, as a result of 
which the work toward use of a CSS is under way; and (ii) ADB has approved the use of CSS at 
the agency level for the Power Grid Corporation of India, and is also in the process of completing 
the national CSS assessment. 
 
4.  The SPS requires ADB to undertake the following, prior to use of CSS: (i) an equivalence 
assessment4 of the DMC policy framework for environment, involuntary resettlement, and/or 
Indigenous Peoples safeguards; and (ii) an acceptability assessment5 of the DMC capacity and 
track record in implementing its own policies and requirements. The CSS assessment process 
also requires ADB to conduct stakeholder consultations on the findings of the assessments, and 
to collaborate with other development partners. Constraints that have so far hampered a more 
expeditious implementation of the SPS provisions on the use of CSS include the considerable 
cost of conducting equivalence and acceptability assessments, and the limited technical expertise 
in applying the CSS assessment methodology as specified in the SPS.  
 
                                                
1  The SPS prescribes a format and methodology for undertaking equivalence and acceptability assessments (SPS, 
paras. 68–69 and Appendix 6). 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 6 June 2017. 
3  ADB. 2016. 2017 Corporate Priority TA Program—Summary of Decisions from the Heads of Departments Meeting. 
Memorandum. 22 November (internal).  
4  A CSS is equivalent to the ADB SPS if the CSS is designed to achieve the objectives and adheres to the policy 
scope, triggers, and applicable principles set out in the SPS (SPS, para. 68[ii] and Appendix 6, para. 10; see also 
ADB. 2010. Draft Guidance Note for Review of Country Safeguard Systems. Manila. para. 10).  
5  Acceptability refers to the extent to which the borrower has the acceptable implementation practice, track record, 
capacity, and commitment to implement the applicable laws, regulations, rules, and procedures in the country, or 
specific sector or agency concerned (SPS, para. 68[ii] and Appendix 6, para. 10; see also ADB. 2010. Draft Guidance 
Note for Review of Country Safeguard Systems. Manila. para. 16).

2 
5.  Once the equivalence and capacity assessments have been completed, and if the CSS is 
found to be broadly aligned with the SPS, a gap-filling action plan will be prepared to ensure CSS 
outcomes are fully in line with SPS requirements. It is noteworthy, in this context, that adoption 
by  India  and  Indonesia  of  landmark  legislation  on  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  has 
encouraged those countries to request ADB to consider the use of CSS. In countries where larger 
gaps in safeguard policies and capacities exist, capacity building will continue and efforts would 
be made on policy and regulatory reforms.   
 
6.  The Independent Evaluation Department, in two evaluation studies of the ADB safeguard 
policy implementation, has recommended to promote the use of CSS through a more strategic 
and  systematic  program  of  action.6 It  also recommended  to  continue  with  ADB’s  cautious 
approach in using CSS. The proposed TA pursues this approach. It will focus on countries with 
promising prospects for a successful application of CSS. In these countries, the TA will support 
the conduct of equivalence and capacity assessments, including the development of gap-filling 
action  plans,  if  required.  It  will  also  undertake  capacity  building  activities  for  government 
counterparts, consultants, and in-country stakeholders on the CSS assessment methodology and 
to close wider gaps in other countries. This approach is expected to generate higher demand in 
these DMCs for use of CSS in lieu of SPS requirements. 
 
7.  Under the completed TA on Strengthening and Use of Country Safeguard Systems,7 ADB 
undertook some groundwork which will support the activities of the proposed TA. ADB initiated 
an exercise to map CSS across Asia and the Pacific in August 2014 under this TA. The objective 
of the CSS regional mapping exercise is to facilitate the strengthening and use of CSS by 
identifying areas of convergence between DMC policy frameworks and the SPS. The TA has 
completed  this  reconnaissance-level  mapping  on  environment  and  involuntary  resettlement 
safeguards in all 40 borrowing DMCs, and for Indigenous Peoples safeguards in 22 DMCs. The 
proposed TA will update the preliminary assessments, as appropriate, to consider relevant 
changes in legislation, and will also complete the mapping on Indigenous Peoples safeguards. 
 
8.  A regional overview of the completed matrices from preliminary mapping shows that there 
are policy frameworks in DMCs in all three safeguard areas. Some of the frameworks are closer 
to the SPS than others as they include legal instruments that can be considered fully or partially 
equivalent to SPS policy principles. For environmental safeguards, Bhutan, the Philippines, and 
Kazakhstan have either full or partial equivalence in all 11 environmental policy principles (SPS, 
p.16). The common equivalence gaps among DMCs are in principle relating to examining project 
alternatives,  cumulative  and  strategic  assessments,  and  disclosure  of  environmental 
assessments. For involuntary resettlement safeguards, India, the Philippines, and Sri Lanka have 
either full or partial equivalence in all 12 involuntary resettlement policy principles (SPS, p.17). 
Common gaps in the involuntary resettlement policy framework  relate to nontitled affected 
persons; preparation, disclosure, and monitoring of resettlement plans; and improving or restoring 
the livelihood of displaced persons. For Indigenous Peoples safeguards, the Philippines policy 
framework is closest to the nine policy principles of the SPS (SPS, p.18) because of the landmark 
1997 Indigenous Peoples Rights Act. For most other DMCs, the common gaps in Indigenous 
Peoples safeguards relate to identification of Indigenous Peoples, consultation and consent 
during project planning and implementation, and provisions for culturally appropriate benefits and 
mitigation measures. 
                                                
6  Independent Evaluation Department. 2014. Safeguards Operational Review: ADB Processes, Portfolio, Country 
Systems, and Financial Intermediaries. Manila; Independent Evaluation Department. 2015. Real-Time Evaluation of 
ADB’s Safeguard Implementation Experience Based on Selected Case Studies. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2010.  Regional Technical Assistance for Strengthening and Use of Country Safeguard Systems. Manila.

3 
 
9.  The preliminary, reconnaissance-level safeguard equivalent matrices, together with the 
legal instruments upon which each assessment is based, have been made available for comment 
to internal and external stakeholders via a CSS web portal.8 These assessments will help in 
identifying countries with better prospects for using CSS and identifying major gaps in countries 
to focus on reforms, and serve as initial data for rigorous CSS assessments when a country 
requests the  use  of  CSS. Thus,  the  proposed TA  will  build  on the  outputs  of the TA  on 
Strengthening and Use of Country Safeguard Systems.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  Based on the design and monitoring framework, the TA is aligned with the following 
impact: environmental and social sustainability of development projects enhanced. The TA will 
have the following outcome: use of CSS in ADB operations supported.9  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities  
 
11.  Output 1: Equivalence and acceptability assessments conducted. For each DMC or 
agency that requests the use of CSS, the TA will support the equivalence assessment of the 
existing policy and regulatory framework, and the acceptability assessment of the agencies 
involved. Based on the assessment recommendations, a gap-filling action plan will be drafted, 
discussed, and endorsed by the relevant government institution, and then finalized. Using the 
assessments and action plan as the basis of due diligence, ensuing projects in the DMC may then 
adopt the use of CSS in lieu of SPS requirements as the benchmark for safeguards. ADB will 
support in-country stakeholder consultations on the assessments and action plan. Under output 
1, the TA will also update preliminary CSS assessment, as needed. 
 
12.  Output 2: Capacity development activities on use and strengthening of country 
safeguard systems undertaken. The TA will support training workshops on the conduct of 
equivalence and acceptability assessments. ADB will train staff of DMC government agencies, 
experts from academe, and consultants on the methodology to assess policy equivalence and 
implementation capacity using the guidance note for country safeguard review.   
 
13.  Output 3: Interagency collaboration on country safeguard systems strengthened. 
The  TA  will  support  collaboration  among  development  partners  to  achieve  harmonized 
approaches to the use of CSS in lieu of financiers’ requirements. Among others, one of the bases 
for this collaboration is the principles of collaboration on country safeguard systems signed by 
ADB, the World Bank, Japan International Cooperation Agency, and Department of Foreign 
Affairs and Trade (Australia) in May 2016. To support the collaboration agreement, the TA will 
prepare  and  disseminate  knowledge  products  on  best  practices  in  country  safeguard 
assessments, and use and strengthening of CSS.10 The TA will conduct a CSS regional workshop 
for knowledge exchange between development partners and DMCs. The TA also will support 
training workshops on environmental and social impact assessment through the safeguard 
                                                
8  CSS web portal: http://countrysafeguardsystems.net/ 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
10 Digital publication will be preferred; however, printed publications will be made available on demand.

4 
learning centers that have been established by the development partners, including in the 
Philippines and Viet Nam.11   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2.     
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. SDCC will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; 
prepare knowledge products; organize workshops; and provide resources for staff to act as the 
resource persons in workshops. In conducting equivalence and acceptability assessments, SDCC 
and the relevant operations department will form country assessment teams composed of staff 
from ADB Headquarters and resident missions. Based on the results of the CSS mapping 
exercise under the TA on Strengthening and Use of Country Safeguard Systems, the potential 
candidates  for  equivalence  and  acceptability  assessments  include  Fiji,  the  Philippines,  the 
People’s Republic of China, and Sri Lanka. The selection of DMCs and/or agencies to be 
supported under the TA will be on a first-come, first-served basis, since CSS assessments are 
conducted on a demand-driven basis (SPS, para. 77). SDCC has undertaken consultation 
meetings with the East Asia Department, Southeast Asia Department, South Asia Department, 
and Pacific Department staff on the potential for CSS assessment in the candidate countries. 
Based on a request from the Government of Sri Lanka, SDCC and the South Asia Department 
fielded a joint consultation mission to Sri Lanka to explain SPS provisions on use of CSS. To 
access TA funds under output 1, operations departments will formally express interest to SDCC 
that a specific DMC has requested ADB to consider the use of CSS.  No funds will be disbursed 
until ADB obtains a no-objection letter from the DMC government concerned. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects   Arrangements

Implementing agencies  Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department and 
operational departments

Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
Source: Asian Development Bank  
 
16.  Consulting services. The TA will involve 78 person-months of services by international 
and national consultants on input-based contracts, including: (i) international CSS experts; (ii) 
national CSS specialists; (iii) a TA coordinator; (iv) a capacity-building specialist; and (iv) a 
national editor. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the 
                                                
11 The World Bank, working with ADB and other development partners, established learning centers in the Philippines 
and Viet Nam for building capacity in safeguards.  Under the same arrangements, similar learning centers will also 
be established in Indonesia, Myanmar, and the People’s Republic of China.

5 
Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time).12  Resource persons from relevant 
organizations with international experience in CSS will be engaged to peer review the TA reports, 
CSS assessments, and knowledge products. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Facilitating the Use of Country Safeguard Systems and Strengthening Safeguards Delivery, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
                   
                                                
12  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
